verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 22:6
verses.text: But knowing that all were false and groundless, he was not affected by the charges brought against him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 22:7
verses.text: Moreover, some of the brethren bore witness that they had heard a demon reproaching Martin in abusive terms, and asking why he had taken back, on their subsequent repentance, certain of the brethren who had, some time previously, lost their baptism by falling into various errors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 22:8
verses.text: The demon set forth the crimes of each of them; but they added that Martin, resisting the devil firmly, answered him, that by-past sins are cleansed away by the leading of a better life, and that through the mercy of God, those are to be absolved from their sins who have given up their evil ways.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 22:9
verses.text: The devil saying in opposition to this that such guilty men as those referred to did not come within the pale of pardon, and that no mercy was extended by the Lord to those who had once fallen away, Martin is said to have cried out in words to the following effect: "If thou, thyself, wretched being, wouldst but desist from attacking mankind, and even, at this period, when the day of judgment is at hand, wouldst only repent of your deeds, I, with a true confidence in the Lord, would promise you the mercy of Christ".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 22:10
verses.text: O what a holy boldness with respect to the loving-kindness of the Lord, in which, although he could not assert authority, he nevertheless showed the feelings dwelling within him! And since our discourse has here sprung up concerning the devil and his devices, it does not seem away from the point, although the matter does not  bear immediately upon Martin, to relate what took place; both because the virtues of Martin do, to some extent, appear in the transaction, and the incident, which was worthy of a miracle, will properly be put on record, with the view of furnishing a caution, should anything of a similar character subsequently occur.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:2
verses.text: A Case of Diabolic Deception.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:3
verses.text: There was a certain man, Clarus by name, a most noble youth, who afterwards became a presbyter, and who is now, through his happy departure from this world, numbered among the saints.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:4
verses.text: He, leaving all others, betook himself to Martin, and in a short time became distinguished for the most exalted faith, and for all sorts of excellence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:5
verses.text: Now, it came to pass that, when he had erected an abode for himself not far from the monastery of the bishop, and many brethren were staying with him, a certain youth, Anatolius by name, having, under the profession of a monk, falsely assumed every appearance of humility and innocence, came to him, and lived for some time on the common store along with the rest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:6
verses.text: Then, as time went on, he began to affirm that angels were in the habit of talking with him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:7
verses.text: As no one gave any credit to his words, he urged a number of the brethren to believe by certain signs.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:8
verses.text: At length he went to such a length as to declare that angels passed between him and God; and now he wished that he should be regarded as one of the prophets.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:9
verses.text: Clarus, however, could by no means be induced to believe.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:10
verses.text: He then began to threaten Clarus with the anger of God and present afflictions, because he did not believe one of the saints.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:11
verses.text: At the last, he is related to have burst forth with the following declaration: "Behold, the Lord will this night give me a white robe out of heaven, clothed in which, I will dwell in the midst of you; and that will be to you a sign that I am the Power of God, inasmuch as I have been presented with the garment of God".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:12
verses.text: Then truly the expectation of all was highly raised by this profession.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:13
verses.text: Accordingly, about the middle of the night, it was seen, by the noise of people moving eagerly about, that the whole monastery in the place was excited.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:14
verses.text: It might be seen, too, that the cell in which the young man referred to lived was glittering with numerous lights; and the whisperings of those moving about in it, as well as a kind of murmur of many voices, could be heard.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:15
verses.text: Then, on silence being secured, the youth coming forth calls one of the brethren, Sabatius by name, to himself, and shows him the robe in which he had been clothed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:16
verses.text: He again, filled with amazement, gathers the rest together, and Clarus himself also runs up; and a light being obtained, they all carefully inspect the garment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:17
verses.text: Now, it was of the utmost softness, of marvelous brightness, and of glittering purple, and yet no one could discover what was its nature, or of what sort of fleece it had been formed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:18
verses.text: However, when it was more minutely examined by the eyes or fingers, it seemed nothing else than a garment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:19
verses.text: In the meantime, Clarus urges upon the brethren to be earnest in prayer, that the Lord would show them more clearly what it really was.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:20
verses.text: Accordingly, the rest of the night was spent in singing hymns and psalms.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:21
verses.text: But when day broke, Clarus wished to take the young man by the hand, and bring him to Martin, being well aware that he could not be deceived by any arts of the devil.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:22
verses.text: Then, indeed, the miserable man began to resist and refuse, and affirmed that he had been forbidden to show himself to Martin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:23
verses.text: And when they compelled him to go against his will, the garment vanished from among the hands of those who were conducting him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 23:24
verses.text: Wherefore, who can doubt that this, too, was an illustration of the power of Martin, so that the devil could no longer dissemble or conceal his own deception, when it was to be submitted to the eyes of Martin?.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:2
verses.text: Martin is tempted by the Wiles of the Devil.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:3
verses.text: It was found, again, that about the same time there was a young man in Spain, who, having by many signs obtained for himself authority among the people, was puffed up to such a pitch that he gave himself out as being Elias.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:4
verses.text: And when multitudes had too readily believed this, he went on to say that he was actually Christ; and he succeeded so well even in this delusion that a certain bishop named Rufus worshiped him as being the Lord.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:5
verses.text: For so doing, we have seen this bishop at a later date deprived of his office.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:6
verses.text: Many of the brethren have also informed me that at the same time one arose in the East, who boasted that he was John.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:7
verses.text: We may infer from this, since false prophets of such a kind have appeared, that the coming of Antichrist is at hand; for he is already practicing in these persons the mystery of iniquity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:8
verses.text: And truly I think this point should not be passed over, with what arts the devil about this very time tempted Martin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:9
verses.text: For, on a certain day, prayer having been previously offered, and the fiend himself being surrounded by a purple light, in order that he might the more easily deceive people by the brilliance of the splendor assumed, clothed also  in a royal robe, and with a crown of precious stones and gold encircling his head, his shoes too being inlaid with gold, while he presented a tranquil countenance, and a generally rejoicing aspect, so that no such thought as that he was the devil might be entertained—he stood by the side of Martin as he was praying in his cell.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:10
verses.text: The saint being dazzled by his first appearance, both preserved a long and deep silence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:11
verses.text: This was first broken by the devil, who said: "Acknowledge, Martin, who it is that you behold.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:12
verses.text: I am Christ; and being just about to descend to earth, I wished first to manifest myself to thee".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:13
verses.text: When Martin kept silence on hearing these words, and gave no answer whatever, the devil dared to repeat his audacious declaration: "Martin, why do you hesitate to believe, when you see? I am Christ".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:14
verses.text: Then Martin, the Spirit revealing the truth to him, that he might understand it was the devil, and not God, replied as follows: "The Lord Jesus did not predict that he would come clothed in purple, and with a glittering crown upon his head.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:15
verses.text: I will not believe that Christ has come, unless he appears with that appearance and form in which he suffered, and openly displaying the marks of his wounds upon the cross".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:16
verses.text: On hearing these words, the devil vanished like smoke, and filled the cell with such a disgusting smell, that he left unmistakable evidences of his real character.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 24:17
verses.text: This event, as I have just related, took place in the way which I have stated, and my information regarding it was derived from the lips of Martin himself; therefore let no one regard it as fabulous.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:2
verses.text: Intercourse of Sulpitius with Martin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:3
verses.text: For since I, having long heard accounts of his faith, life and virtues, burned with a desire of knowing him, I undertook what was to me a pleasant journey for the purpose of seeing him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:4
verses.text: At the same time, because already my mind was inflamed with the desire of writing his life, I obtained my information partly from himself, in so far as I could venture to question him, and partly from those who had lived with him, or well knew the facts of the case.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:5
verses.text: And at this time it is scarcely credible with what humility and with what kindness he received me; while he cordially wished me joy, and rejoiced in the Lord that he had been held in such high estimation by me that I had undertaken a journey owing to my desire of seeing him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:6
verses.text: Unworthy me! (in fact, I hardly dare acknowledge it), that he should have deigned to admit me to fellowship with him! He went so far as in person to present me with water to wash my hands, and at eventide he himself washed my feet; nor had I sufficient courage to resist or oppose his doing so.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:7
verses.text: In fact, I felt so overcome by the authority he unconsciously exerted, that I deemed it unlawful to do anything but acquiesce in his arrangements.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:8
verses.text: His conversation with me was all directed to such points as the following: that the allurements of this world and secular burdens were to be abandoned in order that we might be free and unencumbered in following the Lord Jesus; and he pressed upon me as an admirable example in present circumstances the conduct of that distinguished man Paulinus, of whom I have made mention above.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:9
verses.text: Martin declared of him that, by parting with his great possessions and following Christ, as he did, he showed himself almost the only one who in these times had fully obeyed the precepts of the Gospel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:10
verses.text: He insisted strongly that that was the man who should be made the object of our imitation, adding that the present age was fortunate in possessing such a model of faith and virtue.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:11
verses.text: For Paulinus, being rich and having many possessions, by selling them all and giving them to the poor according to the expressed will of the Lord, had, he said, made possible by actual proof what appeared impossible of accomplishment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:12
verses.text: What power and dignity there were in Martin's words and conversation! How active he was, how practical, and how prompt and ready in solving questions connected with Scripture! And because I know that many are incredulous on this point,—for indeed I have met with persons who did not believe me when I related such things,—I call to witness Jesus, and our common hope as Christians, that I never heard from any other lips than those of Martin such exhibitions of knowledge and genius, or such specimens of good and pure speech.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 25:13
verses.text: But yet, how insignificant is all such praise when compared with the virtues which he possessed! Still, it is remarkable that in a man who had no claim to be called learned, even this attribute [of high intelligence] was not wanting.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:2
verses.text: Words cannot describe the Excellences of Martin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:3
verses.text: But now my book must be brought to an end, and my discourse finished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:4
verses.text: This is not because all that was worthy of being said concerning Martin is now exhausted, but because I, just as sluggish poets grow less careful towards the end of their work, give over, being baffled by the immensity of the matter.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:5
verses.text: For, although his  outward deeds could in some sort of way be set forth in words, no language, I truly own, can ever be capable of describing his inner life and daily conduct, and his mind always bent upon the things of heaven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:6
verses.text: No one can adequately make known his perseverance and self-mastery in abstinence and fastings, or his power in watchings and prayers, along with the nights, as well as days, which were spent by him, while not a moment was separated from the service of God, either for indulging in ease, or engaging in business.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:7
verses.text: But, in fact, he did not indulge either in food or sleep, except in so far as the necessities of nature required.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:8
verses.text: I freely confess that, if, as the saying is, Homer himself were to ascend from the shades below, he could not do justice to this subject in words; to such an extent did all excellences surpass in Martin the possibility of being embodied in language.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:9
verses.text: Never did a single hour or moment pass in which he was not either actually engaged in prayer; or, if it happened that he was occupied with something else, still he never let his mind loose from prayer.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:10
verses.text: In truth, just as it is the custom of blacksmiths, in the midst of their work to beat their own anvil as a sort of relief to the laborer, so Martin even when he appeared to be doing something else, was still engaged in prayer.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 26:11
verses.text: O truly blessed man in whom there was no guile—judging no man, condemning no man, returning evil for evil to no man! He displayed indeed such marvelous patience in the endurance of injuries, that even when he was chief priest, he allowed himself to be wronged by the lowest clerics with impunity; nor did he either remove them from the office on account of such conduct, or, as far as in him lay, repel them from a place in his affection.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:2
verses.text: Wonderful Piety of Martin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:3
verses.text: No one ever saw him enraged, or excited, or lamenting, or laughing; he was always one and the same: displaying a kind of heavenly happiness in his countenance, he seemed to have passed the ordinary limits of human nature.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:4
verses.text: Never was there any word on his lips but Christ, and never was there a feeling in his heart except piety, peace, and tender mercy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:5
verses.text: Frequently, too, he used to weep for the sins of those who showed themselves his revilers—those who, as he led his retired and tranquil life, slandered him with poisoned tongue and a viper's mouth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:6
verses.text: And truly we have had experience of some who were envious of his virtues and his life—who really hated in him what they did not see in themselves, and what they had not power to imitate.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:7
verses.text: And—O wickedness worthy of deepest grief and groans!—some of his calumniators, although very few, some of his maligners, I say, were reported to be no others than bishops! Here, however, it is not necessary to name any one, although a good many of these people are still venting their spleen against myself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:8
verses.text: I shall deem it sufficient that, if any one of them reads this account, and perceives that he is himself pointed at, he may have the grace to blush.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:9
verses.text: But if, on the other hand, he shows anger, he will, by that very fact, own that he is among those spoken of, though all the time perhaps I have been thinking of some other person.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:10
verses.text: I shall, however, by no means feel ashamed if any people of that sort include myself in their hatred along with such a man as Martin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:11
verses.text: I am quite persuaded of this, that the present little work will give pleasure to all truly good men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:12
verses.text: And I shall only say further that, if any one read this narrative in an unbelieving spirit, he himself will fall into sin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Life of Saint Martin 27:13
verses.text: I am conscious to myself that I have been induced by belief in the facts, and by the love of Christ, to write these things; and that, in doing so, I have set forth what is well known, and recorded what is true; and, as I trust, that man will have a reward prepared by God, not who shall read these things, but who shall believe them.
